answer_html: Make sure you visibly identify the maximum and inflection point on your sketch of the function.
hints_html: Try incorporating the answers from parts a - d in order: first draw the x-intercepts, then where the graph increases and decreases, and finally adding the concavity.
hints_latex:
Try incorporating the answers from parts a - d in order: first draw the
x-intercepts, then where the graph increases and decreases, and finally
adding the concavity.
hints_raw: Try incorporating the answers from parts a - d in order: first draw the x-intercepts, then where the graph increases and decreases, and finally adding the concavity.
question: 3 (e)
sols_html:
The function’s value is zero at each end of the interval [0,\(\pi\)], we have found a maximum at \(\pi\)/4 and an inflection point at \(\pi\)/2 so your sketch should look something like the plotted function here.

Make sure you visibly identify the maximum and inflection point on your sketch of the function.

\emph{{[}0,$\pi${]}}, we have found a maximum at \emph{$\pi$/4} and an
inflection point at \emph{$\pi$/2} so your sketch should look something like
the plotted function here.

sols_raw:
The function's value is zero at each end of the interval ''[0,&pi;]'', we have found a maximum at ''&pi;/4'' and an inflection point at ''&pi;/2'' so your sketch should look something like the plotted function here.

Make sure you visibly identify the maximum and inflection point on your sketch of the function.
statement_html:
Let \(f(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{e^{x}}\) on the interval \([0, \pi]\). In this question you will sketch this function.

(e) Make a large sketch of the graph of \(f\) below, including all you have found in the previous parts of the question.
statement_latex:
Let $f(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{e^{x}}$ on the interval $[0, \pi]$. In this
question you will sketch this function.

\textbf{(e)} Make a large sketch of the graph of $f$ below, including all
you have found in the previous parts of the question.
statement_raw:
Let <math> f(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{e^{x}} </math> on the interval <math> [0, \pi] </math>. In this question you will sketch this function.

'''(e)''' Make a large sketch of the graph of &fnof; below, including all you have found in the previous parts of the question.
